title: Lupita Nyong'o holds a copy of her new children's book, Sulwe, outside a Barnes & Noble in NYC
text:
She first found stardom as Patsey in 12 Years A Slave, before her role as feisty Nakia in Black Panther catapulted her to worldwide fame.

Now Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong'o, 36, is an author, too, with the publication of her first children's book, Sulwe.

The proud star turned up for a book signing at a Barnes & Noble in Union Square in New York City on Friday.

Scroll down for videos

Author! Lupita Nyong'o was seen at her book signing for Sulwe at Barnes & Noble at Union Square on Saturday

She looked stunning in a black coat that she wore over a dark blue sweater with silver stars and a white blouse with a pointy collar.

Lupita completed her look with a dark blue skirt patterned with tiny silver stars and high-heeled black pumps with silver toe caps.

With her hair in her signature short black curly style, she wore dark glass and carried her book in one hand.

Fashionista: Lupita stunned in a black coat that she wore over a dark blue sweater with silver stars and a white blouse with a pointy collar

So chic: Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong'o, 36, seen outside Barnes & Noble in Union Square, NYC, on Friday holding her new children's book, Sulwe

Special message: Lupita's children's book, Sulwe, is about a young black girl who doesn’t think she's beautiful because of the color of her skin

Sulwe is about a young black girl who doesn’t think she's beautiful because of the color of her skin.

She then goes on a journey of self-love and acceptance before recognizing her beauty from within.

Lupita told GMA this week that she wrote Sulwe because seeing light-skin characters in children's books books such as Cinderella made her feel 'uncomfortable' about her skin color when she was a child.

Fashion forward: She accessorised her look with trendy sunglasses

Book with a message: 'It took a while for me to...learn to love the skin I'm in,' she said adding, 'I wrote this book to help little kids get there a little faster'

'In fact, one of the first times I drew my family, I drew them with light skin. I used the cream-colored crayons and not the dark ones because I just didn't see that in books. I didn't think we belonged in books.'

'It took a while for me to find my stride and learn to love the skin I'm in,' she said adding, 'I wrote this book to help little kids get there a little faster.'

Sulwe means Star in the Luo dialect of Dholuo, spoken by some 6 million Luo people in Kenya and Tanzania, who live in parts of the eastern shore of Lake Victoria and areas to the south.
